High up in the growing mountain chain of what would one day be called Yello=
w Stone park two figures stood. One was tall and slender, the other only sl=
ightly shorter, the details of their forms were lost in the dark shadows of=
 the cave where they stood. 

The area outside the cave bore little resembl=
ance to the beautiful and idyllic settings that would one day be here. Inst=
ead the land looked almost battle scarred as the ground was mostly stone an=
d dirt, with only a few tuffs of grass. Decades ago a massive volcanic erup=
tion had swept over the area burning away the vegetation and life that had =
once grown here. Only now was the hand of nature was making itself once aga=
in felt here as spots lifeless volcanic rock were grudgingly giving away to=
 new life and small plants were beginning to grow. Some distance away a riv=
er forded itself along what was once a major lava flow, but so far only sma=
ll bits of life was yet able to survive in the waters.

It was to this view=
 that the two figures stood, only the red ember of their glowing optics cou=
ld be made out in the darkness. 

=E2=80=9CI have always found this view ca=
lming=E2=80=9D said the taller of the two figures, his voice thoughtful. 

=
=E2=80=9CYou would.=E2=80=9D said the other, his voice somewhat deeper, his=
 voice sarcastic, yet with a hint of respect, even as he himself also crane=
d his head to look out at the scene. =E2=80=9CHmph! Even this ball of dirt =
has its destructive side.=E2=80=9D

=E2=80=9CYes.=E2=80=9D said the first, =
obvious by his tone, the leader of this duo. =E2=80=9CAll things do, if we =
can only find it.=E2=80=9D

The taller figured stepped forward, allowing th=
e cold sun=E2=80=99s rays to reveal the purple hues of his armored form. He=
 glanced back at his companion, =E2=80=9CScourge, the time to depart this p=
lace has come, I believe *they* have returned.=E2=80=9D

Scourge nodded as =
he too stepped forward, the revealing the blues and blacks shades of his fo=
rm and the wing-like projections that sprang from his back. =E2=80=9CI can =
smell the odor of their vapor trails even from here.=E2=80=9D

Cyclonus gla=
nced back at Scourge, wondering not for the first time, the true range of h=
is companion=E2=80=99s tracking ability. =E2=80=9CWe must return to Megatro=
n. He still holds the spark of what was once Galvatron.=E2=80=9D

Scourge n=
odded, =E2=80=9Cbut what if he is still not ready. He seemed . . . differen=
t.=E2=80=9D His voice sounding a bit unsure as he watched his leader.

=E2=
=80=9CHe will be ready.=E2=80=9D Cyclonus said with a quiet confidence that=
 he could not quite make himself believe. =E2=80=9CThe Unicronians will for=
ce him to be.=E2=80=9D

Cyclonus leaped into the air, followed smoothly by =
Scourge, the twin sounds of gears grinding accompanying their transformatio=
n into thier aerial forms. Explosive gasses and flames light up the air as =
Cyclonus climbed into the skies. 

=E2=80=9CAnd what if he=E2=80=99s not?=
=E2=80=9D Scourge said as he followed his leader higher into the air. 

Cyc=
lonus said nothing as he continued to climb into the skies, leading them ba=
ck towards what perhaps might be either their home or their next battle gro=
und =E2=80" he set course for the black tower.  

(And so it begins . . . )=


Preston
(Cyclonus & Scourge)
